To the right honorable my very singular good Lord, the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.
17 Ap
r
1591
M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
The offence of
e
states
towardes
S
r
Edward Norris
.
The Elecc
o
n of
Counte Maurice
to
e Government of
Gueldres
./
17 Ap
r
91
fol.339r
May it please yo
r
good L. This day I recea-
ved her
Hig
nes
letter to
e General states, and
an other to my self, w
ch
was written by yo
r
L. the 9 of this moneth, and wholy concer-
ned the affaires of
Ostend.
The letter to
e
states I delivered assoone as it came to my
handes. And because I founde in
e reading,
w
ch
was done in my presence, in
e assembly of
the states, that it was an answear to a letter
w
ch
e
Councel
of late had sent unto her Ma
tie
I excused
e erro
r
aswell as I could, and
shewed that
e writer, in
e indorsing of
e letter,
had mistaken
e states for
e Councel of state.
Howbeit there was a meeting both of
e states
and of
e Councel, to consider upon
e mater
recommended in
e letter: wherein they rest
affected, as I have formerly signified, and
as yo
r
L. may perceave by their answear to
her Ma
tie
. They speake against the Governo
r
w
t
very muche passion, and lette me say w
at
I
list, it will nothing prevaile: that I see in the
end they will ether be masters, or take some
other course that may easely marre all.
Yo
r
L. may remember, that at Midsomer
last
e states of Guelders made choise of Count
Maurice, to succeede
e
Count de Meurs
, in
e
government of
e Duchie of Guelders, and the
Countie of
Zutphen.
The Councel of state,
and likewise
e Count himself lett them then
understand; that
e forme of their Election
was against the 24 Article of
e Treaty w
t
her Ma
tie
by w
ch
it is provided, that in every
suche vacation of a Governo
r
, the Province it self
fol.339v
shall nominat two or three persons, of w
ch
the
Councel of state shall make election of one.
The states of Guelders therupon writte letters
of intreaty in December last, that albeit their
order of proceeding was not wholy in forme ac-
cording to
e Treaty, yet because Count Maurice
was sufficiently q
a
lified, and
e meetest person
for
e place, that it would please
e Councel
in that respect, to dispense w
t
e forsaid Article,
and ratifie
e Election already made. It was
a mater muche debated in sundrie consulta-
tions, and as I am persuaded, had bin quietly
caried against
e meaning of
e Contract, but
that I opposed somw
at
earnestly against it.
For I urged precisely
e observation of the
forme, alleaging mine othe that bound me unto
it, a particular charge by reason of my place,
and
e danger of
e consequence, if the Councel
should dispense w
t
any point of
e Treaty.
For as it was concluded by her Ma
tie
and the
states, so in case of dispensation, w
t
out her Hig
nes
assent their actions were frustrat. Wherupon
for that time there was nothing done in
at Election.
But as this day those of Guelders ether fin-
ding of the mselves their owne erro
r
, or admo-
nished from hens by some of
e Councel, have
uelded to proceede as
e Treaty requireth,
and
[.]
in a newe nomination have joined
Grave John
of
Est Frise
w
t
Count Maurice.
Howbeit, the other being named but for forme,
e Election of this Councel is past upon Count
Maurice.
Having no other mater to
advertise yo
r
L. I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. A
p
17 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
fol.340r
Heere is come intelligence right nowe, that
the companies in Guelders, w
ch
were sent,
as in my last I advertised yo
r
L. to surprise
the towne of Straelen, have taken
e repulse.
There are two Englishe Captaines a litle hurt,
to witte Cap
t
Wray, and Cap
t
Clifford, of
e
common souldiers some twenty, and seven or
eight slaine.
]
